text.p: Following are the main stories in today's Malaysian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- Malaysia offers to help Indonesia put out forest fires in Sumatra island. The fires are blamed for a haze surrounding most of Peninsular Malaysia and causing air pollution problems
-- Privatisation of state agency to help ethnic Malays, Mara Holdings Bhd, has been awarded to a consortium led by Nadzmi Mohd Salleh, former managing director of Proton, the national car maker.
-- Malaysia will amend the land code to make high-rise apartment owners to get title for the property easily.
-- Government may tax speculators in a move to curb volatility in the Malaysian ringgit, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said.
-- The Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange is at a price-to-earnings ratio of 15 times, which is very attractive to buy, KLSE president Salleh Abdul Majid said.
-- The newly launched Multimedia Super Corridor zone for high technology companies will contribute up to $25 billion in the first five years to the nation's economy

-- About 50 percent of the total industrial investment of over 85 billion ringgit in Malaysia's economy in the 1985-96 period was contributed by foreigners, the Malaysian Industrial Development Authority Zainal Abidin Sulong said.
